article.title: Spatiotemporal expression and control of haemoglobin in space
article.abstract: It is now widely recognised that the environment in space activates a diverse set of genes involved in regulating fundamental cellular pathways. This includes the activation of genes associated with blood homeostasis and erythropoiesis, with a particular emphasis on those involved in globin chain production.

sections.introduction: An interesting phenomenon that has been observed in studies related to space medicine and biology is the clinical phenotype associated with space anaemia.
sections.methods: The NASA Twins Study involved two male twin subjects, aged 50 years old at the time of launch.
sections.results: Obtained globin gene, transcription factor (TF) and globin miRNA expression results are hereunder showcased for the NASA Twins study, the JAXA study as well as the Inspiration4 mission.
sections.discussion: The switch from fetal to adult haemoglobin after birth is well-known but not fully understood.

article.insights_summary: The study examines the developmental expression of haemoglobin over time and space using multi-omic datasets from NASA GeneLab. The findings reveal significant variations in globin gene expression corresponding to the distinct spatiotemporal characteristics of the collected samples.
article.acknowledgments: We would like to extend our gratitude to the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) for the data on their Japanese astronauts.
